feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Montgomery

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 5:52AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
At 552 AM AST, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 36 miles northeast of St John to 18 miles south of Charlotte Amalie West. Movement was northeast at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
entry.cap:areaDesc: St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands

cap:parameter.value: STRONG THUNDERSTORMS WILL IMPACT SAINT JOHN AND SAINT THOMAS COUNTIES THROUGH 715 AM AST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 4:45AM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary:
At 444 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Franklin, or near Fort Madison, moving quickly northeast at 50 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could cause minor tree limb damage and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Burlington, Fort Madison, Monmouth, Oquawka, West Burlington, West Point, Donnellson, Stronghurst, Kirkwood, Little York, Middletown, Carman, Biggsville, Gladstone, Rozetta, Franklin, Gulf Port, Niota, New Boston, and Iowa Army Ammunition Plant.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Des Moines; Lee; Mercer; Henderson; Warren; Hancock

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of northwestern Warren, south central Mercer, Henderson, north central Hancock, southern Des Moines and northern Lee Counties through 530 AM CDT

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 18 at 2:36AM PDT until October 19 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...Through this evening. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 4:24AM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog will impact portions of north central, central and far northeast Wisconsin early this morning. Motorists should anticipate locally hazardous travel conditions, with visibilities reduced to less than one-quarter mile at times. The fog will mix out between 8 am and 9 am.
If you are traveling and encounter fog, slow down and leave extra room between you and the car in front of you. Be sure to use your low beam headlights.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Vilas; Oneida; Forest; Florence; Northern Marinette County; Lincoln; Langlade; Northern Oconto County; Marathon; Wood; Portage

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 18 at 2:08AM PDT until October 18 at 12:00PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement. A moderate risk of sneaker waves. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 20 to 25 feet expected.
* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.
* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through Saturday morning. For the High Surf Advisory, from 11 AM Sunday to 11 AM PDT Monday.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath. Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will continue to build through Saturday morning and linger through the day Saturday. After brief improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high surf are expected late Sunday into early Monday with the highest waves peaking out Sunday night.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON PDT TODAY... ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM SUNDAY TO 11 AM PDT MONDAY

* WHERE...All beaches of Douglas, Coos and Curry Counties.

* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath. Large breaking waves will create hazardous conditions along and within the surf zone, and could inundate beaches and low lying shorelines. Beach erosion is possible, and exposed infrastructure may be damaged.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The risk of sneaker waves will continue to build through Saturday morning and linger through the day Saturday. After brief improvement Saturday night, hazardous conditions due to high surf are expected late Sunday into early Monday with the highest waves peaking out Sunday night.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 3:59AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
Fog is expected to be around through the early morning hours in northeast Iowa. Some areas could see dense fog with visibilities to 1/4 mile or less.
If traveling in northeast Iowa this morning, be cautious and be ready for rapid changes in visibility in the fog. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.
The fog should dissipate between 8 and 10 am.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mitchell; Howard; Winneshiek; Floyd; Chickasaw; Fayette

cap:parameter.value: Expect Fog in Northeast Iowa This Morning

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 3:59AM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary:
Fog will develop over portions of eastern Iowa early this morning and last through the mid morning hours before dissipating. The fog could become locally dense with visibilities down to a quarter mile at times.
If you are headed out this morning, be prepared for rapid changes in visibility over short distances, keep plenty of stopping distance in front of you, and use your low beam headlights.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Buchanan; Delaware; Dubuque; Benton; Linn; Jones; Iowa

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 18 at 3:56AM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
entry.summary:
WHAT...Patchy fog with visibilities around or under a half mile
WHERE...Much of central Iowa
WHEN...through 8am
IMPACTS...Drivers should be alert for reduced visibility at times.
PREPAREDNESS AND PRECAUTIONARY ACTIONS...If driving this morning, please use low beam headlights.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued October 18 at 4:42AM AST until October 18 at 6:45AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
FFWSJU
The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Saint Thomas in Virgin Islands...
* Until 645 AM AST.
* At 442 AM AST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Saint Thomas, VI

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 6:45 AM AST. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 6:45 AM AST. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued October 18 at 2:11AM MDT until October 19 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 216, 239, 241, 246 and 247.
* TIMING...Sunday afternoon.
* WINDS...Southwest 10 to 15 mph with gusts to 25 to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Conditions will be favorable for rapid fire spread. Avoid outdoor burning and any activity that may produce a spark and start a wildfire.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued October 18 at 4:06AM EDT until October 19 at 5:00AM EDT by NWS Key West FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor saltwater flooding.
* WHERE...Florida Keys.
* WHEN...Through early Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...Minor saltwater flooding of low elevation streets and lots is likely. Some storm drains will overflow, and some seawalls and docks will be overtopped. Boaters can expect less clearance under fixed bridges. Motorists should remember that persistent puddles around the times of high tide are almost certain to contain a mix of saltwater. In the Upper Keys, there will be little relief in minor salt water flooding, even at around the times of high tide.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Monroe Upper Keys; Monroe Middle Keys; Monroe Lower Keys

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT

* WHERE...Beartooth Foothills and Livingston Area.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 3 PM MDT Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Gusty winds will blow around unsecured objects. Strong crosswinds will make travel difficult along Interstate 90 from Livingston to Big Timber and roads along the Beartooth Foothills.

cap:parameter.value: WIND ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 6 PM THIS EVENING TO 3 PM MDT SUNDAY

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued October 18 at 3:49AM AST until October 20 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents.
* WHERE...From Northwest to east-facing beaches, including beaches of Aguada and Rincon, and Culebra.
* WHEN...Through late Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water, where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A stronger pulse of the long period northerly swell will reach the northern coastal areas by Sunday likely prompting the issuance of additional High Rip Current Statements and also High Surf Advisories.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; North Central; Northwest; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Culebra

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 18 at 3:36AM EDT until October 18 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves expected in the surf zone.
* WHERE...The beaches north of Cape Hatteras.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT Saturday through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 12:30 PM Saturday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Outer Banks; Hatteras Island

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING THROUGH THIS EVENING NORTH OF CAPE HATTERAS

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 8:34PM PDT until October 19 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sneaker waves possible.
* WHERE...North and Central Coast of Oregon, and South Washington Coast.
* WHEN...For the first Beach Hazards Statement, from this evening through Saturday evening. For the second Beach Hazards Statement, from Sunday afternoon through Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...Waves can run up significantly farther on a beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Sneaker waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the frigid ocean which may lead to serious injury or drowning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when sneaker waves create potentially life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Caution should be used when in or near the water. Always keep an eye on the waves, and be especially watchful of children and pets.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Clatsop County Coast; Tillamook County Coast; Central Coast of Oregon; South Washington Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued October 17 at 11:01PM EDT until October 19 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one half foot of inundation above ground level expected in low lying areas due to tidal flooding.
* WHERE...Shoreline in Anne Arundel County.
* WHEN...Until midnight EDT Saturday night, especially around the time of high tide.
* IMPACTS...At 2.8 feet, flooding of some of the parking area near Dock Street in Annapolis may occur, with water surrounding the Alex Haley Memorial.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Tides one to one and a half feet above normal. The next two high tides at Annapolis U.S. Naval Academy is at 3:47 AM and 4:17 PM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Anne Arundel

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM TO 10 AM EDT SATURDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued October 17 at 8:54PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
St Johns River Near Astor affecting Lake and Volusia Counties.
.The St Johns River at Astor remains in Moderate Flood Stage due to recent rainfall and downstream impacts from tides and surge. The river is forecast to remain steady or slowly fall within Moderate Flood Stage through this weekend and into early next week. However, tide and wind effects could periodically slow the decline.
For the St. Johns River...including Astor...Moderate flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Saturday morning at 1100 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Johns River near Astor.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 3.0 feet, Water approaches or may enter lowest homes on or near Wildhog Road and nearby canals. Flooding reaches the parking lot of the Juno Trail Apartments. Flooding on portions of Alligator Road and Holiday Road. Lowest lying yards along Blue Creek are flooded. Roads at Astor Landing Campground and Lake Dexter Boat Ramp begin to flood. Water enters lower homes closest to the river on McPherson Lane.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Friday the stage was 3.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 2.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:30 PM EDT Friday was 3.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 3.2 feet. - Flood stage is 2.3 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake, FL; Volusia, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:49PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: A couple waves of energy will bring the potential for snow squalls Saturday through Sunday night. Squalls are notoriously quick in nature, but can bring brief heavy bursts of snow and wind gusts up to 35 mph which can reduce visibility below 1 mile at times. Snow accumulations of 1 to 3 inches is possible, with the heaviest expected in the Western Seward Peninsula and most of it coming Saturday night through Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Snow Squalls Possible Saturday and Sunday

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 17 at 2:48PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary: Light snow fell overnight and during the day Friday across many parts of the Interior. Most accumulations were on the order of 1 to 3 inches. While most roadways have remained wet as opposed to icy today, that could change overnight. Additional light snow is expected later tonight and throughout the day Saturday. In addition most areas will see temperatures drop into the upper 20's to near 30 degrees overnight which could result in some icy conditions for local roadways overnight tonight and early Saturday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River; Fortymile Country; Delta Junction; Upper Chena River Valley; Tanana Flats; Eielson AFB and Salcha; Goldstream Valley and Nenana Hills; Chatanika River Valley; Two Rivers; Fairbanks Metro Area; Nenana; Central Interior; Northern Denali Borough; Southern Denali Borough; Eastern Alaska Range North of Trims Camp; Eastern Alaska Range South of Trims Camp

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued October 17 at 12:36PM PDT until October 18 at 11:00PM PDT by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A long period northwesterly swell will result in an increased risk for sneaker waves and rip currents.
* WHERE...San Francisco, Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore, San Francisco Peninsula Coast, Northern Monterey Bay, Southern Monterey Bay, and Big Sur Coast.
* WHEN...From 8 PM PDT this evening through Saturday evening.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can unexpectedly run significantly farther up the beach than normal, including over rocks and jetties. Rip currents are typically more frequent and stronger in the vicinity of jetties, inlets, and piers. Swimmers should always swim near a lifeguard.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Francisco; Coastal North Bay Including Point Reyes National Seashore; San Francisco Peninsula Coast; Northern Monterey Bay; Southern Monterey Bay and Big Sur Coast
